claim: Vaccination with a higher-dose recombinant flu vaccine may induce a more robust antibody response than egg-based standard-dose vaccines.

verified_snippets.quote: Data from a randomized, controlled trial demonstrated that children 6 months to less than 3 years of age had diminished hemagglutinin inhibition (HI) responses to Flublok compared to a U.S.-licensed influenza vaccine approved for use in this population, strongly suggesting that Flublok would not be effective in children younger than 3 years of age (6).
verified_snippets.relevance_explanation: This quote demonstrates that antibody responses (measured by HI) can differ between Flublok (a recombinant vaccine) and standard egg-based vaccines, supporting the idea that vaccine formulation and dose can affect antibody response.
verified_snippets.actual_text: Data froma randomized, controlled trial demonstrated that children 6 months to less than 3 years of age had diminished hemagglutinin inhibition (HI) responses to Flublok comparedtoaU.S.-licensedinﬂuenzavaccineapprovedforuseinthispopulation, strongly suggesting that Flublok would not be effective in children younger than 3 years of age (6).
differences: Spacing differences: 'froma' vs 'from a', 'comparedtoaU.S.-licensedinﬂuenzavaccineapprovedforuseinthispopulation' vs 'compared to a U.S.-licensed influenza vaccine approved for use in this population'

verified_snippets.quote: Keitel WA, Treanor JJ, El Sahly HM, et.al. Comparative immunogenicity of recombinant influenza hemagglutinin (rHA) and trivalent inactivated vaccines (TIVs) among persons ≥65 years old. Vaccine. 2009, Vol. 28, pp. 379-385.
verified_snippets.relevance_explanation: This reference is cited in the context of clinical studies comparing the immunogenicity (antibody response) of recombinant (higher-dose) and standard egg-based vaccines, supporting the claim that such comparisons have been made and may show differences in antibody response.
verified_snippets.actual_text: Keitel WA, Tre an or JJ, El Sahly HM, et.al. Comparative immunogen i city of recom- bin ant inﬂuenza hemagglutinin (rHA) and trivalent in activated vaccines (TIVs) among persons ≥65 years old. Vaccine. 2009, Vol. 28, pp. 379-385.
differences: Spacing differences in author name: 'Treanor' vs 'Tre an or'
Spacing differences in 'immunogenicity': 'immunogenicity' vs 'immunogen i city'

verified_snippets.quote: Flublok contains recombinant HA proteins of the three strains of influenza virus specified by health authorities for inclusion in the annual seasonal vaccine. These proteins function as antigens which induce a humoral immune response measured by hemagglutination inhibition (HI) antibody titers.
verified_snippets.relevance_explanation: This quote establishes that Flublok (a recombinant vaccine) is designed to induce an antibody response, measured by HI titers, which is the standard for assessing vaccine-induced immunity.
verified_snippets.actual_text: Flublok contains recombinant HAproteins of the three strains of inﬂuenza virus speciﬁed by health authorities for inclusion in the annual seasonal vaccine. These proteins function as antigens which induce a humoral immune response measured by hemagglutination
differences: The document text is truncated and does not include the full phrase 'measured by hemagglutination inhibition (HI) antibody titers.' but does include 'measured by hemagglutination', which is a partial match.

verified_snippets.quote: For the 2024-2025 influenza season it is formulated to contain 135 mcg HA per 0.5 mL dose, with 45 mcg HA of each of the following 3 influenza virus strains...
verified_snippets.relevance_explanation: This quote provides evidence that Flublok is a higher-dose vaccine (135 mcg total HA per dose), which is relevant to the claim that higher-dose recombinant vaccines may induce a more robust antibody response compared to standard-dose vaccines.
